articles.title: Bare: A New Lightweight Runtime for Modular JS Apps
articles.description: Imagine something like Node.js but really stripped back: bare, if you will. Like Node, it’s built on top of V8 and libuv (though it's designed to support multiple JavaScript engines) but Bare’s approach is to provide as little as possible (a module system, addon system, and thread support) and then rely upon userland modules that can evolve independently of Bare itself. It’s an interesting idea – more details here.
articles.author: Holepunch

articles.title: An Update on the Deno v Oracle JavaScript™ Fight
articles.description: Deno filed a petition with the USPTO to cancel the 'JavaScript' trademark, as claimed by Oracle, and Oracle stepped up to fight back. Ryan recaps the basic story and asks for help to get the word out (signing the open letter is a great start, if you agree Oracle abandoned the trademark).
articles.author: Ryan Dahl

articles.title: React 19.1 Released
articles.description: The headline feature is Owner Stacks, a dev-only feature to track which components are responsible for rendering other components. 19.1 also brings fixes, small additions (like support for streaming in edge environments), a new API for prerendering RSCs on the server, and enhanced Suspense support.
articles.author: Matt Carroll (Facebook)

articles.title: Exploring Art with TypeScript, Jupyter, Polars, and Observable Plot
articles.description: One of Deno’s compelling features is its support for Jupyter Notebooks and easy notebook-style programming, such as is common in the Python world. Trevor looks at a practical use of using such a notebook environment for data exploration.
articles.author: Trevor Manz

articles.title: Could JavaScript Have Synchronous await?
articles.description: Dr. Axel reflects on the problems around async code being different to synchronous code and ways around the limitations faced. What could the consequences of a synchronous await be?
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: JavaScript's Missing Link? Wasp Offers a Full Stack Solution
articles.description: A look at what the Wasp team is trying to do building a full-stack webapp framework around React, Node, and Prisma. It’s a powerful option if you’re looking for a more traditional-feeling full-stack approach.
articles.author: Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

articles.title: Anime.js 4.0: A JS Animation Library for the Web
articles.description: If you’re tired of Web animations, maybe Anime.js will refresh your appetite. This is a major upgrade to a mature library for animating CSS properties, SVGs, the DOM, and JS objects. It’s smooth, well-built, and now complete with fresh documentation.
articles.author: Julian Garner

articles.title: Milkdown 7.7: WYSIWYG Markdown Editor Framework
articles.description: A WYSIWYG Markdown editor framework based around a plugin system that enables a high level of customization. The docs are rendered by Milkdown itself. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Mirone

articles.title: TinyBase v6.0: A Reactive Data Store for Local-First Apps
articles.description: We’re huge fans of this powerful reactive data store that can be used as the entire backend for many types of app. v6.0 adds no new functionality but brings React 19 support and goes ESM-only. Check out the homepage for more.
articles.author: James Pearce

articles.description: Safari 18.4 has been released with Declarative Web Push support, iterator helpers, Error.isError, and faster JSON.parse and JSON.stringify functions.

There's a longstanding proposal to bring TS-style enums to JavaScript and author Ron Buckton will be pitching it to TC39 at its next meeting. Here's a slidedeck covering the benefits. Thanks to Rob Palmer for highlighting this.
The ES2025 spec has reached candidate stage in anticipation of being finally approved in June.
Express 5.1 – The long standing Node.js web framework gets a bump with 5.x finally becoming the latest tagged version on npm.
React Email 4.0 – Components and tools for rendering HTML emails.
zx 8.5 – Google's tool for better Node shell scripting.
Astro 5.6, Ember 6.3, Turborepo 2.5, Node.js v23.11.0, Bun v1.2.8

articles.title: Minimal CSS-Only Blurry Image Placeholders
articles.description: An experimental, pure CSS technique for producing blurry, low-quality image placeholders, using just a single custom property. Beyond just sharing the clever technique, the post also dives into how it all works, exploring the limits of CSS variables and radial gradients. There’s a gallery filled with examples here. It's a smart little hack, but one that I found didn't play nice in Safari.
articles.author: Lean Rada

articles.title: Better Typography with text-wrap: pretty
articles.description: Support for improved text wrapping has just shipped in the latest preview of Safari. Here, Jen shares a look at what this update means, noting that it brings “an unprecedented level of polish to typography on the web”. There’s a solid demo here that highlights all of the wins, but you’ll need to view it in Safari Technology Preview 216.
articles.author: Jen Simmons (WebKit)

articles.title: Overengineered Anchor Links
articles.description: Anchor links can often be an issue if the linked content is at the bottom of the page, so here’s a surprisingly meaty exploration of the fixes — going way beyond simple padding, and diving into mathematical equations to solve the issue via a custom mapping function. Formulas, visualizations, and more!
articles.author: Mats Erdkamp

articles.title: Top 5 CSS Navigation Menu Mistakes
articles.description: Runs through some of the most common UI gotchas found within navigation menus, such as unforgiving target areas on dropdowns.
articles.author: Zoran Jambor

articles.title: Use shape() for Responsive Clipping
articles.description: Support for the CSS shape() function is now slowly rolling out — you can expect it to work in Chrome 135 and Safari 18.4. As such, here’s a quick look at how it can be used with clip-path for responsive clipping — there's a demo here. Ana Tudor has also chucked together a 'breathing box' demo.
articles.author: Noam Rosenthal

articles.title: More Accurate DevTools Performance Debugging using Real-World Data
articles.description: The latest on Chrome’s ongoing efforts to improve the DevTools Performance panel — this time with a focus on CPU throttling calibration, and data-driven improvements.
articles.author: Brendan Kenny

articles.title: Background Image Opacity in CSS
articles.description: A quick look at the options available for controlling opacity, including ‘blending’ via RGBA, pseudo elements, and an experimental cross-fade function.
articles.author: Jim Nielsen

articles.title: ▶  Modern CSS Theming, Light Mode, Dark Mode and More
articles.description: A roughly half hour look at what modern CSS features we can use to create dark and light themes and how to save user preference to localStorage.
articles.author: CJ (Syntax)

articles.title: Making :visited More Private
articles.description: Here’s how Chrome now prevents any potential privacy leaks that use visited links as an attack vector.
articles.author: Kyra Seevers

articles.title: Cover Flow with Modern CSS: Scroll-Driven Animations in Action
articles.description: The Cover Flow feature on the iPod was super cool, so this scratches a certain nostalgic itch.
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: CSS Bursts with Conic Gradients
articles.description: Some neat little experiments and demos here.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: Tailwind CSS v4.1: Text Shadows, Masks, and Tons More
articles.description: A new version of Tailwind CSS dropped just a few days ago, adding text-shadow utilities, the ability to mask elements, fine-grained text wrapping, improved browser compatibility, and much more.
articles.author: Wathan & Hollick (Tailwind CSS)

articles.title: UA+: User Agent Plus
articles.description: If you’re after a better baseline for your stylesheet Manuel has a work-in-progress CSS reset that is worth a look. “Instead of mostly resetting and normalizing properties, we focus on improving existing user agent styles and adding new styles only where browsers fall short”.
articles.author: Manuel Matuzović

articles.title: Lighthouse Scoring Calculator: A Small Playground for Understanding Lighthouse Scores
articles.description: This tool lets you fiddle around with some hypothetical values calculated by Lightouse so you can get a rough idea of which values have a bigger effect on the overall score.
articles.author: Chrome for developers

articles.title: Record: Open-Source Web App to Record Screen and Camera Directly in the Browser
articles.description: Another media-related project from Addy, this one is actually a fork of an older project with some modern enhancements. You can give it a spin here.
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: Khroma: An AI Color Tool to Design with Colors You Love
articles.description: An interesting method for generating color palettes. You choose 50 colors you like (saved in localStorage), which personalizes the algorithm to give you palettes based on your favorite colors.
articles.author: George Hastings
